titlestmt.author: Compiled by Carl S. Miller

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 00:14

did.unittitle: The Paul Hindemith Collection

langmaterial.language: Materials chiefly in German and English.

did.abstract: Music, correspondence and other papers, photographs, and additional materials by and about the German composer Paul Hindemith (1895-1963).

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The Papers are open to researchers by appointment. There are no restricted materials in the collection. Please contact the Special Collections staff to schedule an appointment. Some of the materials may be stored at the Library's off-campus shelving facility, so researchers should allow at least two business days to have the appropriate boxes paged.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Paul Hindemith Collection was assembled and curated by Luther Noss from 1964 to 1993. In 1993 the Collection was transferred to the Music Library of Yale University.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Paul Hindemith Collection is the physical property of the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University. Copyrights belong to the composers and authors, or their legal heirs and assigns.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: MSS 47, The Paul Hindemith Collection in the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: In 13 series as follows: I. Materials Relating to Hindemith's Compositions. II. Speeches, Writings and Teaching Materials. III. Collegium Musicum. IV. Additional Concerts and Teaching Materials. V. Correspondence and Journals. VI. Articles about Paul Hindemith. VII. Biographical Materials. VIII. Photographs and Drawings. IX. Personal Correspondence. X. Miscellaneous Materials XI. Holograph Materials. XII. Oversize Items. XIII. Sound Recordings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Paul Hindemith Collection brings together primary and secondary source materials which document the life and career of Paul Hindemith, particularly his years in the United States (1940-1953). The Collection holds holographs of 14 compositions by Hindemith, including the Lilacs Requiem and the concertos for clarinet, horn, and trumpet and bassoon. The Collection also holds secondary materials (programs, notes, and reviews) for nearly all of Hindemith's compositions, as well as extensive material relating to Hindemith's classroom teaching and the Yale Collegium Musicum. Additional materials include correspondence between Paul and Gertrud Hindemith and colleagues, friends, and music publishers; photographs and drawings; articles about Hindemith; and miscellaneous materials.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Paul Hindemith (1895-1963) was born in Hanau, Germany. A prodigious child violinist, he left school early to study at the Hoch Conservatory in Frankfurt-am-Main. As a teenager he was already a professional string quartet performer and soon became leader of the Frankfurt Opera orchestra, under the direction of Ludwig Rottenberg, whose daughter, Gertrud, later became Mrs. Hindemith.

Hindemith studied composition under Bernhard Sekles and Arnold Mendelssohn and soon established himself at the forefront of the post World War I avant-garde. When the Nazis came to power in the 1930s, his music was banned, but not before he was firmly established as a distinguished teacher of composition at the Berlin Hochschule. Since his wife had a Jewish father, he decided to seek another residence, going first to Switzerland and in 1940 to the USA, joining the faculty of the Yale University School of Music, where he remained until his official departure for Europe in 1953.

The Paul Hindemith Collection at Yale University was established in 1964 and was under the supervision/curatorship of Prof. Luther Noss from its inception to 1993. The Collection is primarily a repository for secondary documents relating to the composer's life and work in the United States. The initial gathering of materials was implemented by a weekend commemorative concert series at the University in 1964, following soon upon the death of the composer. At that time many associates sent materials for exhibition purposes, after which much was acquired by the Collection, either as gifts or purchases.

Yale's Paul Hindemith Collection has enjoyed a close association with the Paul Hindemith Foundation, a private and nonprofit Swiss corporation that holds title to the entire Hindemith estate by the bequest of the composer's wife, Gertrud Hindemith, and the Paul Hindemith institute in Frankfurt-am-Main which is subsidized by the Foundation. Yale's Collection has been strengthened significantly by copies from the Frankfurt archives of all the correspondence and other accounts left by Paul and Gertrud Hindemith that relate to their experiences in the United States. In addition, there are copies of correspondence dating back to 1917 and forward to 1965. This time frame exceeds the actual period of 1937 (the year of Hindemith's first concert tour of the USA) to 1953 (his return to Europe) and his death in 1963.

The Collection contains a profusion of newspaper and periodical articles, clippings, concert reviews, and programs; reports from American and foreign newspapers; many private Journal entries; voluminous business correspondence with B. Schott's Söhne, Mainz, and Associated Music Publishers, Inc., New York, Schott's American agent; and personal correspondence with prospective and former students, colleagues, and friends. Its holdings also include many original drawings- made by the composer while living in New Haven, Connecticut, and many photographs of him and his wife: at home, in action - teaching, conducting, composing, with students and colleagues, and formal portraits.

Original holographs are few but significant, comprising a câche of concertos written here: Concerto for Clarinet and orchestra for Benny Goodman; Concerto for Horn and Orchestra; Concerto for Trumpet, Bassoon, and String Orchestra; Sonate Ober alten Volkslieder (XXX.) for organ; sketches for Thema mit vier Variationen, a.k.a. The Four Temperaments; pièces d'occasions known only to the participants, typically American songs, and the entire score of "When lilacs last in the dooryard bloom'd."

As complete as possible is the documentation of the Collegium Musicum performances of late medieval, Renaissance, and baroque music under Paul Hindemith's direction at Yale and Harvard Universities. Also included are the repeated performances at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, with programs, lists of personnel, working copies of the music, reviews, accountings, etc.

The post-WW2 controversy brought about by the vitriolic written attacks of Theodor Adorno is well covered, including many defenses by peers and former students. In addition, virtually everything published in German has been translated into English by Prof. Noss, comprising all the prefaces to the Gesamtausgabe and the many articles contained in the Hindemith Jahrbücher. Even the libretti of the operas and German song texts are available in English. Without the years of dedication and devotion by Professor Noss to the task of collecting, filing, ordering, translating, studying, advising, and corresponding, this collection would not exist.
Recordings of works by Paul Hindemith and those he conducted himself repose in the Yale Collection of Historical Sound Recordings and are not listed in this register.

The Paul Hindemith Collection greatly enriches the Yale University Music Library's extensive collection of composers, papers, including those of Charles Ives, Virgil Thomson, Kurt Weill, Carl Ruggles, Horatio Parker, Richard Donovan, Quincy Porter, J. Rosamond Johnson, Lowell Mason, Henry Gilbert, Harold Rome, and Lehman Engel.

did.unittitle: MATERIAL RELATING TO HINDEMITH'S COMPOSITIONS

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I presents the sequence of materials relating to Paul Hindemith's compositions as they were collected by Luther Noss. Arranged roughly in chronological order, each composition is assigned one or more folders which contain documents, reviews, articles, and commentaries. With a few exceptions, there are no published scores in the Collection; these are contained in the reference and circulating collections of the Yale University Music Library. In addition, works by other composers which were edited for publication or arranged by Hindemith appear in the chronology.
The Box numbers and Folder numbers are consecutive throughout the Collection. Oversized items are housed in Box 43. The holographs, slightly larger than average, are contained in Boxes 31-32.
Cross references are made where a photocopy or holograph could not be fitted into the consecutive numbering of Boxes or Folders because of its size.
Programs and reviews of performances are filed under the title of the composition.
Beginning with Folder 118, most letters listed under composition title are excerpts, complete texts of which may be found among the Correspondence in Boxes 15-17 and Boxes 21-23.

SPEECHES, WRITINGS, AND TEACHING MATERIALS

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Speeches, writings, and teaching materials are housed in Boxes 910. They contain, among other items, versions of "The Craft of Musical Composition, Parts I-II-III-IV," materials and proofs for "Traditional Harmony, Parts I-II," "Elementary Training for Musicians," "The Composer's World," autographed copies of the lecture on J. S. Bach in English and German, and other writings. Some additional materials may be found in oversize Box 43.

COLLEGIUM MUSICUM

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Collegium Musicum materials are housed in Boxes 11-12, with additional materials in oversize Box 43. Folders in Boxes 11-12 are arranged chronologically by performance. The materials include those performed at Yale University and in 1950 at Harvard University. Many of the scores from 1943 are holographs. Most of the scores after 1947 are in Paul Hindemith's hand, duplicated from holograph offset masters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: During the weekend of 7-8 November 1964, the year following the composer's death, the Yale School of Music held a celebration commemorating Paul Hindemith at Yale. This event included three concerts and an exhibition in Beinecke Library of scores, letters, drawings, student projects, concert programs, and other memorabilia. Records of this commemoration, including photographs, are contained in Box 13.

Also contained in this series are copies of special examinations Paul Hindemith prepared for entering students, projects the composer completed in class, student projects, degree requirements, class notes, and materials related to his teaching of theory, composition, the history of theory, and his musicianship training program.
Complete lists of students enrolled in his classes, lists of composition and theory majors, and programs of composition students are also contained in Box 13.

Preceding Parts III and IV of "The Craft of Musical Composition" are files containing materials from other Hindemith festivals held at Yale University, Eugene, Oregon, Ohio State University, The University of Kentucky, and various cities in Germany (Box 13).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence between Paul Hindemith and his publishers and with his wife Gertrud Hindemith, including his Journal entries, is contained in Boxes 16-17, arranged in chronological order. Personal correspondence with friends, colleagues, and former students is housed in Boxes 21-23.

Communications between Paul Hindemith-Gertrud Hindemith, Paul Hindemith-W. Strecker, Paul Hindemith-E. Voigt, and Paul Hindemith-K. Bauer are autograph letters signed in German unless otherwise indicated. The Schott Archives in Mainz and the Hindemith Institute in Frankfurt hold the original documents and retain all rights of publication.

ARTICLES ABOUT PAUL HINDEMITH

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Articles in English before 1964 (Folder 300) and after 1964 (Folders 301-302) are mostly drawn from American and British periodicals and are not all favorably disposed toward the composer. Articles from the Hindemith Jarhbücher (Folders 303-306) were selected and translated by Luther Noss. Sometimes an entire volume appears in translation; other times only one or two articles are translated. Other excerpts from the Jahrbücher may be found under Series VII - Biographical Materials (see especially Folder 326) and elsewhere in this register.

The foreign articles before 1940 (Folder 307) reveal the enthusiasm young Hindemith's music received and his many difficulties with the Nazi authorities. Those from 1946-1988 show the ambivalent attitudes still prevailing among his German and American critics along with a genuine appreciation of his accomplishments by others (Folders 309-311).

Newspaper stories and articles are American, German, Norwegian, and Swedish in origin (Folder 313). Though most newspaper and periodical reviews of individual compositions are contained in Folders 1-223, reviews of Paul Hindemith as orchestral conductor and soloist are filed chronologically in Folder 314.

Folder 315 contains many obituaries from periodicals and East and West Coast newspapers. This Folder also holds programs of memorial concerts and portions of Paul Hindemith's burial service in Switzerland.

BIOGRAPHICAL MATERIALS

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gathered here are numerous items collected by Luther Noss which contribute to the biography of Paul Hindemith. Personal Recollections comprise a set of articles, letters, interviews, and reminiscences. Folder 324 contains biographical information gleaned from orchestral programs, booklets, magazine articles, standard musical encyclopedias, and personal comments from friends, colleagues, and former students.

Folder 326 contains the earliest letters from Paul Hindemith (1916-1922) covering his period of service in the German army. A list of holograph manuscripts and letters found at the Library of Congress is contained in Folder 330.

Also represented is a plaque installed in Sprague Memorial Hall, Yale University, in 1976 by the National Music Council Bicentennial Committee. The correspondence, text of the plaque, and newspaper articles covering this occasion are found in Folder 332.

PHOTOGRAPHS & DRAWINGS

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs of Paul and Gertrud Hindemith are arranged chronologically and cover the years 1931 to 1973. Besides many informal poses, there are official portraits of Paul Hindemith by the Yale University New Bureau, copies of all the Christmas cards drawn by Paul Hindemith, a number of his original drawings, and a catalogue of an exhibition of Hindemith's drawings held in 1986.

Additional photographs and photocards may be found in the Personal Correspondence, Series IX/Folders 339-355. The Easter Eggs Hindemith painted for Ralph Kirkpatrick are in Box 34. The 14 paintings on butcher paper which Hindemith created for Carl Lohmann's 25 anniversary celebration at Yale are found in Boxes 36-42. The window shade painted for the farewell party in 1953 is housed in Box 35.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence in Boxes 21-23, Folders 338-356, is with personal friends, colleagues, students, and Paul Hindemith's lawyer, Oscar Cox. The bulk of letters dates from 1937 to 1966. Business letters between Hindemith and his publishers are found in Boxes 15-17, Folders 282-299, while letters pertaining to his professional life are found in Box 19, Folder 326.

This series also contains a number of photocards; i.e., postcards bearing a photo of Paul Hindemith or Gertrud & Paul Hindemith, many of which are not included in Series VIII, Photographs & Drawings. The photocards emanate from Salzburg, New York, Vienna, Bayreuth, Munich, and Hamburg.

MISCELLANEOUS MATERIALS

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series X comprises miscellaneous materials, including complete copies of all official documents pertaining to Paul Hindemith's appointment to the Yale University faculty, his leave of absence to lecture at Harvard University, and his resignation in 1953. Other folders in this series contain duplicate Christmas cards and holograph scenarios for two unproduced ballets: The Children's Crusade" and "The Parable of the Blind," prepared for Leonid Massine and George Balachine.

Additional folders in this series include class exercises and student projects (Folders 363-373); lists of writings, speeches, and lectures deposited in the Hindemith Institute in Frankfurt (381) ; information on the founding of the Institute and Foundation; correspondence relating to the Yale Hindemith Collection; and a listing by the Deutsches Rundfunkarchiv of Paul Hindemith as a conductor and soloist in recorded and live performances in Europe (399).

HOLOGRAPH MATERIALS

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 16 musical holographs in the Yale University Hindemith Collection include songs for children and professionals, concertos, the Requiem, sketches for The Four Temperaments, Organ Sonata No. 3, and a 5-part canon. Two songs (Folders 431 & 436) were composed for Carl Lohmann, Secretary of Yale University from the mid-1940s to the early 1950s. Lohmann possessed a fine singing voice and could read music at sight. This material is unknown outside a small circle of New Haven residents.
The score of "Lilacs" was presented to the collection by Gertrud Hindemith after the composer's death.

Oscar Cox, the poet who provided the texts to Hindemith's songs "Image" and "Beauty Touch Me," was a lawyer in Washington, D. C. Cox guided through Congress the release of Hindemith's royalties which had accrued in the office of the U. S. Alien Property Custodian throughout World War II and afterwards.
